newsitem.title: USA: Worldwide semiconductor revs fall - Dataquest.
newsitem.headline: Worldwide semiconductor revs fall - Dataquest.

text.p: Worldwide semiconductor revenues fell seven percent to $141 billion in 1996, market research firm Dataquest said Tuesday.
Dataquest attributed the decline to a steep drop in the dynamic random access memory (DRAM) market.
The semiconductor market suffered in 1996 as the average selling price for DRAMs fell by three-fourths, Dataquest said.
Dataquest said that, excluding DRAM, the 1996 semiconductor market grew by six percent, led by a 14 percent microcomponent revenue growth.
Intel Corp remained the world's number one chip producer, gaining momentum with 29 percent growth in revenues. It had overall market share of 12 percent in 1996, Dataquest said.

Intel's 1996 revenues of about $16.9 billion were nearly $6 billion more than those of second-place NEC Corp, which saw a six percent decline in revenues. NEC had 7.5 percent market share, Dataquest said.
Motorola Inc saw revenues drop three percent to $8.4 billion, leaving it with a six percent market share.
